Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2012 09:16PM littlecatsfeet wrote: I have a regularly-scheduled appointment in two weeks; my oncologist said to keep tabs on the pain and call him if it gets worse.  He also said that next time I feel like running around the woods for the weekend, to act like an adult and have a glass of wine instead :-) My onc is all about the wine and ice cream :-) On a side note - man, I felt those shots today.
Posts.Title: Faslodex, activity and pain: when to be concerned littlecatsfeet littlecatsfeet

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2012 07:59AM littlecatsfeet wrote: Chris62, thanks for that post - it was so difficult telling my kids about my recurrence. I think I need to have another talk with them, with your post in mind. I am only 4 months into this mets journey. Discovered at my onc appointment yesterday that our first drug of treatment - good old Arimidex, which I was on for 5 years (and was taken off of 1.5 years ago as per protocol) - isn't working, as my markers jumped from 153-253. He said that he wasn't surprised, put me on faslodex, and let me know that chemo was next on the list should faslodex not work. Up until then I had been doing well, even planning for future adventures! - but the past 24 hours have been blue blue blue. I'm so glad I read this thread - this is the kind of encouragement I need, especially when my mom already has me 'dying'. Leslie

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2012 11:38AM littlecatsfeet wrote: I had my ovaries removed the same year I was first diagnosed in 2005. Very easy surgery to recover from, at least in my experience. I want to say that I was back at work in days, but honestly I can't remember (one of the many things I've put out of my mind).
Posts.Title: anyone have a oophrectomy done stellaratovsky stellaratovsky

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2012 12:13PM littlecatsfeet wrote: Just wanted to let you know that my infusuion (and the days following) was A BREEZE compared to what I went through with Zometa. Was able to function at work, and my crazy-a$$ weekend of volunteering was both fun and exhausting - but no side-effects! I was actually on a boat stoking the fires at this: waterfire.org/ until midnight on Saturday - what a difference!!  Thank you all for your input - my oncologist is probably sick of me bringing you all up at my visits, but truly, I would be hard pressed to continue any part of this journey without every one of you.
